The most commonly used physical separation process for enriching uranium is the gaseous diffusion process. This process involves the separation of uranium hexafluoride (UF6) gas through a semipermeable membrane. The UF6 gas is passed through the membrane under high pressure, and the lighter U-235 molecules are able to pass through the membrane more easily than the heavier U-238 molecules. This results in a higher concentration of U-235 in one side of the membrane and a lower concentration of U-235 in the other side. The U-235-rich side is then enriched further through repeated diffusion processes.
Another physical separation process used for enriching uranium is the gas centrifuge process. This process involves the separation of UF6 gas by spinning it in a centrifuge at high speeds. The U-235 molecules are separated from the U-238 molecules due to their different centrifugal forces. The U-235-rich gas is then enriched further through repeated centrifuging processes.
Both gaseous diffusion and gas centrifuge processes are used in the enrichment of uranium. The choice of process depends on the specific requirements of the enrichment plant and the type of uranium being processed.
